qas.question: Why is there difficulty in defining process theology ?

answers.text: process theologians are so diverse and transdisciplinary in their views and interests

qas.question: What subjects has John B. Cobb, Jr. written books on other than process theology?
What theories do Roland Faber and Catherine Keller combine with Whitehead's ideas?
What was Charles Birch's profession besides theologian?
Who authored "Syntheism - Creating God in the Internet Age"?
Why is there no difficulty in defining process theology?
What subjects has John B. Cobb, Jr. burned books on other than process theology?
What theories do Roland Faber and Catherine Keller not combine with Whitehead's ideas?
What wasnt Charles Birch's profession besides theologian?

context: In fact, process theology is difficult to define because <a0_0>process theologians are so diverse and transdisciplinary in their views and interests<a0_0/>. John B. Cobb, Jr. is a <b5_0>process theologian<b5_0/> who has also written books on <a1_0><b6_0>biology and economics<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Roland Faber and Catherine Keller integrate Whitehead with <a2_0><b7_0>poststructuralist, postcolonialist, and feminist theory<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Charles Birch was both a theologian and a <a3_0><b8_0>geneticist<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Franklin I. Gamwell writes on theology and political theory. In Syntheism - Creating God in The Internet Age, futurologists <a4_0>Alexander Bard and Jan Söderqvist<a4_0/> repeatedly credit Whitehead for the process theology they see rising out of the participatory culture expected to dominate the digital era.
